Once you interrogate this notion you realise the audience in the North East [of England], for example, is a very dferent tribe from those in the South."You get this throughout Scotland as well. The iety of what you find leaves you confused. At times you donrsquot know where you are.But there is a commonality, I ask. Arent we all in the same boat ndash one which seems to be sinking  He doesnrsquot think so. ldquoWersquove been through everything, from invasion to natural disaster to famine to religious fundamentalism, he says. ldquoWersquove been through civil war, wars of independence, the industrial revolution, two world wars. All of this has unfolded in the same tapestry. This is just a period in history. In a  years there will be dferent issues and a dferent set of politics.Thatrsquos a comfort. Sort of. But meantime, what do we do about Brexit, Neil  ldquoI donrsquot want to deal in that, he says, placing his coffee cup down with a slightly emphatic clump, suggesting hersquos learned to avoid controversy. ldquoIrsquom careful not to offer an opinion on any of that. My tour aim is to put an arm around the shoulder of someone I care about, which is this archipelago. Itrsquos a love letter to the British Isles, a spectacular place which has looked after me, and now itrsquos my turn to look after him ndash or her.He offers a thought: ldquoThe motto of the Isle of Man, lsquoWhichever way you throw me I will standrsquo, the three legged symbol, I think thatrsquos a great motto for people to live by.Thatrsquos easy to say, but wersquore facing confusion, polarisation of politics, right-wing extremism. You must be afraid of the isions politics has produced and the invective that comes with it  It seems everyone wants to be angry.ldquoIrsquom sick of politics, he admits. ldquoIrsquom completely disenchanted with all of it. Politicians lack so much knowledge. If Irsquom honest, I donrsquot think therersquos a politician out there worth listening to, of any creed or colour. I donrsquot have any truck with any of them. Irsquom just looking away at the moment while they do what they do, which is self-aggrandizing and performing their Punch and Judy nonsense. I cannot be bothered with it.He adds: ldquoI was in that arena vaguely for a while on account of a few opinions I was invited to give.He certainly was. Oliver incurred the wrath of the Nationalists back in  when he declared independence for Scotland a "dead dog."But does he now regret becoming involved in the independence debate He pauses for thought. ldquoNo, I think itrsquos important to say what you think is true. But I donrsquot like the atmosphere at the moment whereby you canrsquot say what you think. If you are not pleasing the social media mob you are silenced or destroyed. I was asked some questions and I gave an honest answer.Oliver rejects the offer of half a sconeand instead sips at his coffee cup. ldquoHow it really started for me was when I was being interviewed for Bannockburn  [his TV show] and a journalist asked me about the referendum. ldquoI remember saying, lsquoA referendum is like going shopping for food when yoursquore hungry.rsquo You donrsquot want to be making snap decisions.Because you come away with a packet of Hobnobs and a jar of Nutella  ldquoExactly. I donrsquot think we should have referendums to decide which side of the road we should drive on, never mind kicking the ball back to the general population to determine a nationrsquos destiny. Thatrsquos why we have political democracy, whereby we employ hundreds of people to read tedious paperwork, shout and bawl at each other in a room for as long as it takes. Thatrsquos why these -odd people have a job.He becomes more animated. ldquoReferendums are a bad idea. After the Scottish referendum there were immediate cries for another one. lsquoThat disnae countrsquo. Now therersquos been Europe. And that was seen to be wrong. And so you claim for another one. What do you do  Go for best of three  Or best of five Oliver smiles. ldquoIrsquove never been a card-carrying member of a political party. I used to scoff at university friends who were. In the same way I couldnrsquot understand why anyone would get excited about football. Irsquom not minded that way.Yet, but he is minded to recognise how politics overlaps into culture and issues of identity, which he loves to wax lyrical about on his TV shows. But there are those who donrsquot countenance his passion for explaining the likes of Iona and the coming of Christianity. Some, such as Professor Tom Devine, see Oliver as an irritant.The historian once attacked the fact Oliver had been asked to front a History of Scotland ndash given he didnrsquot have a degree in history.Oliver didnrsquot take Devinersquos comment laying down however, describing the historian as being like of the old grumps from The Muppets.More recently, Oliver got it in the neck when appointed president of the National Trust for Scotland, and many Nationalists demanded his removal, which seemed odd given the TV presenterrsquos passion for this space we live in.But the writer presenter took it on broad shoulders. Did his personal history prepare him for the future stre  Seems so. Hersquos used to adjustment. ldquoI was born in a council flat in Renfrew, my dad moved to Ayr to work [he was a commission salesman] and then to Dumfries. The family was ldquocomfortable, he says. It certainly wasnrsquot an Angelarsquos Ashes set in Scotland storyline. They even managed a holiday to Spain once.Yet, the man who would go on to explain the Picts and Vikings and anacyclosis to uswasnrsquot top of the class at school. ldquoI was in the upper half but I wasnrsquot so great at maths and science so I focused on English and history, which I was quite good at.Oliver was blessed with encouraging parents who most likely were baffled why their son wanted to study archaeology, University I fell in love with the prospectus given it rarely leads to a career. ldquoI did work as an excavator for a few years going on digs, he recalls. ldquoIt was fun, but there was no money in it. And during the winters it became a bit grim.One Friday afternoon he was excavating the Roman Road in Greenock, and on the Monday he was covering a peace protest in Lockerbie for the local newspaper. Why the switch to journalism ldquoI liked the idea of journalism because it was essentially noseyness about people, he explains, grinning. ldquoItrsquos a bit like archaeology in that itrsquos the chance to poke through the rubbish, to find out what people were doing and why. Instinctively, I want to know who, what, where, why and when.Journalism has been as important to his current career, he says, as his time spent scraping dirt with a big spoon. ldquoWhen Irsquove been cast in the likes of Coast as a presenter it helped me get something out of people. And this Magpie-like work taught me how to become engrossed in a subject for a day then drop it, and move onto something .The curious mind continued to search for the next adventure and in  he joined a BT internet company. ldquoI thought that may be my future. I was also fascinated to learn how it had evolved, largely financed by the US military, who wanted to knowcomputers could survive after a nuclear attack. And so they hired these hippies to find out. And then I wondered what do we do with it  What are the consequences of it He answers his own question: ldquoItrsquos created titans such as Mark Zuckerberg, and Amazon, Google and Pay Pal. He adds in soft, serious voice, ldquoNow, Zuckerberg is almost at the point he has more power than Putin, without the missiles.While working for the internet company, Oliver decided to set off for Zululand.ldquoI had met up with my close pal from university Tony Pollard one day in the Granary Bar in Glasgowrsquos Shawlands and we came up with the idea of going to Zululand to make a film [which became the BBCrsquos  documentary, Two Men In A Trench].Boldness has to be part of the reason for Oliverrsquos success. He had a good job, with a good salary, a car and an Amex account. ldquoBut I didnrsquot have a mortgage. I wasnrsquot married. I could take a chance. And I knew I had had experience. When the TV job ran out Irsquod do something .Does the job flipping suggest a malcontent  ldquoNo, when I was at BT I figured Irsquod give it a couple of years, he says with a wee hint of umbrage in his voice for me having suggested such a thing. ldquoAnd we made the film really because we wanted to go to South Africa. The voice warms again: ldquoArchaeology was my first love and we met again. It was like Friends Reunited. And wersquove been together ever since.Hersquos a television natural. But did he always feel confident speaking to the camera  ldquoYes. Irsquove always had a good memory and Irsquom lucky in that I can remember  words in the right order, he says, grinning. ldquoTalking to the camera is not a natural thing to do. Itrsquos like a golf swing. But some people can do it. And I enjoyed being with these like-minded people. It was quite collegiate. I loved it from the get-go.Oliver landed on the box at the right time. ldquoI was   when television began to happen for me. I had few delusions about my own reality. Irsquod been in a few dferent jobs, had the rougher edges knocked off by le experience. Irsquod filled shelves at Presto supermarket while eating the Mars Bars. Irsquod worked on an MS till. He adds, with a wry smile, ldquoIrsquod been dumped often enough by women.Women. Yes, now hersquos married to one. And history taught him he should incorporate this woman into his future. Oliver met his future we Trudi when he was at university. ldquoI was in third year at the time, the president of the archaeology society and she was in first year, and she came in to join. I made a bee-line for her when she walked in the door.He grins. ldquoI donrsquot think she was as impressed by me as I was by her.She must have liked him a little because the pair were together for seven years. ldquoAnd it just sort of fizzled out. Then, years later, I met her wee brother Johnny and we swapped numbers and a few months after that I was back in touch with Trudi. It was asIrsquod seen her the day before.He reflects: ldquoThatrsquos another great thing about my le. Whatever happens, I know Irsquom with someone who remembers me when I was  and a silly arse. She remembers me when I had all sorts of archaeology student affectations, all patchouli oil and cheese cloth shirts. We can remember the teenagers we were.Oliver reveals he had the long hair back in the day. He didnrsquot create the soft Tarzan look for telly. He has just never bothered to have it cut. And it works for him, gives him a USP, although watching him on TV with the wind blasting into his face as he stands on a clf edge he does have to brush it away from his mouth a little too often but, I suppose, a kirby grip or a hair scrunchy would wreck the image.He laughs. ldquoIrsquove been holding out for the Head and Shoulders contract for  years but itrsquos never happened.Therersquos a calm about Oliver, even though he does become animated when he talks about the politics he says he wants nothing to do with. And he clearly loves his le, beaming at the delights of a career which allows him to take his family adventuring in the likes of Australia and New Zealand while filming Coast. Yet with three children hersquos not immune to worry, about the impact of social media, for example. ldquoPeople can have , friends, but ironically they have never been more isolated and lonelier. People go to Facebook ndash I donrsquot ndash hoping to see other people in this clearing in the forest who are equally lonely.Hersquos happy however, very happy. ldquoThe thing I most love these days is writing. I wrote as a student, as a journalist and then in TV with scripts. Irsquove written ten books or so and itrsquos something Irsquoll be able to do.And now hersquos making live appearances. ldquoIrsquove sort of blundered into them. Irsquom out there talking about our world, like Simon Reeve and Dan Snow. Maybe I can do this every year. Why not So the world will be all right, Neil  We need you to tell us it will be. ldquoWe tend to think this is a modern concern, but perhaps Stonehenge and Avebury are partly expressions of feeling the same concerns, people feeling they are little specks in the great scheme of things and wanting to be heard, to make a mark.He grins, reassuringly. ldquoWersquoll be fine, but I wonrsquot beI donrsquot do this school pick-up in time.Neil Oliver ndash The Story of the British Isles in  Places, the Theatre Royal, Glasgow, November .

title: scotlands-insider-guide-stornoway
story: But therersquos so much more to the Hebridean capital than just great views. Indeed, this bustling port on the Isle of Lewis has a thriving arts, culture and food scene that puts many bigger mainland towns to shame.Itrsquos also a place to soak up Gaelic hospitality, history and tradition, while appreciating the ever-changing terrains of this magical, wind-swept isle.Historical HighlightsKnown as Stjoacuternavaacutegr, or ldquosteering bay in Old Norse, Stornoway was founded by the Vikings in the early th century, people have inhabited Lewis for around  years.The main street, Cromwell Street, is named for Oliver Cromwell, whose forces fought to take control of the town in .Owned by the Mackenzies of Seaforth for more than  years, Lewis was sold to Sir James Matheson for pound, in . The new laird built Lews Castle, which still overlooks the bay, as well as many of the islandrsquos roads and schools.With its sheltered harbour and strategic location, Stornoway played a key role in both world wars. On New Yearrsquos Day , HMY Iolaire ndash Gaelic for eagle ndash sank in the harbour, killing at least  men ing home from the First World War.Oban guideAccording to the  census,  per cent of residents in greater Stornoway speak Gaelic. More than , people now live in the town, employed mainly in the tourism, textile, seafood and offshore industries.Things to doFirst things first, get your bearings with a jaunt around the harbour. Yoursquoll see boats of all shapes and sizes, from the huge CalMac ferry - Loch Seaforth - that transports locals and visitors to and from Ullapool, to fishing boats, leboats and pleasure crafts that populate the ious piers and marinas. The Sail Stornoway festival takes place every July, attracting hundreds of boats from all over Scotland and beyond.As you take in the sights and smells of the seafront there are plenty of places to stop for coffee, snacks or fish and chips. Itrsquos also worth walking up to the headland at the Holm Point end, where the poignant memorial to the Iolaire disaster stands.The walk along the seafront also takes you straight to An Lanntair , the arts, culture and community hub that opened in . A theatre, cinema, live music venue, art gallery, dance studio and more, it also has a fantastic cafeacute bar and shop, and with a full programme of events and exhibitions all year round, therersquos always something to see. Forthcoming highlights include the Dark Skies Festival, in February , which features an eclectic mix of music, visual art and science.Oban guideIts also well worth popping into the Town Hall to see the newly-installed Harris Tweed Story, told by the authoritythat certies the world-renowned fabric with its famous orb. Looms take centre stage alongside dferent types of products and a visual and audio guide that helps explain what makes the tweed, which can only be woven on Harris or Lewis, so special.Lews Castledeserves a whole day of your time. Home to the excellent Museum nan Eilean and some of the mysterious Lewis Chessmen, it has a full programme of exhibitions reflecting island le and history, including the current one, which focuses on the Iolaire. The stunning grounds, meanwhile, make for wonderful walking no matter the season, with the trees ndash a rarity on the island ndash providing welcome shelter from the wind. If yoursquore feeling lazy, a guided Segway touris the ideal way to whizz around. Therersquos a great cafeacute, too, which has ldquothe best scones in Stornoway, according to Jan Patience.Itrsquos worth remembering that many people on Lewis are very religious and consider Sunday to be a special day of the week. Most commercial activity stops, and the vast majority of businesses are closed, though ferries and flights now operate.Where to eatThe Cafeacute Bar at An Lanntair is a relaxed affair that serves delicious food from am till pm, complete with great sea views. The chowder, made with local ingredients, is a hearty meal in itself.Seafood fans are certainly spoiled for choice in Stornoway. Upmarket Digby Chick , run by chef-proprietor James Mackenzie, showcases the best of locally caught fish and shellfish. The Minch turbot served with mussels and chive butter is simply sensational, and the early bird menu offers great value at pound. for three courses.Oban guideIf itrsquos a good fish supper yoursquore after ndash and who isnrsquot  ndash Cameronrsquos on Point Street doesnrsquot disappoint. CalMac also serves up excellent fish and chips in comfortable surroundings on the ferry to and from Stornoway. The macaroni cheese also gets five-star reviews.HS- at the Royal Hotelon Cromwell Street offers tasty burgers and wraps, served in a cosmopolitan, buzzy atmosphere, and for those who like their food spicy, the popular Thai Cafeacute lets you bring your own bottle.For coffee and cake, Lewis resident Kathryn Lamont Smith is a big fan of the Blue Lobster on the waterfront. ldquoI love this place, she says. ldquoAs well as being my favourite cafeacute, it is also a lovely gt shop. Kopi Java, on Cromwell Street, meanwhile, pulls in locals and visitors alike with its gourmet coffee and hot chocolate. The empire biscuits arenrsquot half bad, either.Where to shopHarris Tweed Hebrideson Cromwell Street is the place to go for all your tweed needs, from beautul tailored jackets, trousers, waistcoats and skirts, to accessories and home interiors.The lovely Hebridean Hobby Centre , also on Cromwell Street, has a full range of crafting materials, from wools and fabrics to modelling kits.Yoursquoll also want to stock up on the local food before you leave, from the world famous, geographically protected Stornoway black pudding made by Charles MacLeodand sold from the shop in Ropework Park, to the exquisite smoked salmon from the family-run Stornoway Smokehouse on Shell Street .The Good Food Boutique , back on Cromwell Street, has an array of quality deli foods from home and abroad, and also serves great coffee.Where to stayLuxury: Natural Retreats Lews Castlehas beautul apartments in the castle grounds, overlooking the harbour, from pound a night.Mobile: You can be king of the Hebridean road in this modern camper van, complete with fitted kitchen, which sleeps four. Comes with parking. From pound a night. Listed on Airbnb.Famous facesBBC Scotland and Alba presenter Cathy Macdonald is from Stornoway, as is actor Hans Matheson, who has appeared in TV shows such as Tess of the DrsquoUrbervilles, The Tudors and Jericho.Hollywood screenwriter Aeneas Mackenzie, writer of films including They Died With Their Boots On, Ivanhoe  and The Ten Commandments, was born in Stornoway in .Things to do nearbyIf you do only one other thing on Lewis, visit the extraordinary Neolithic standing stones at Calanais,  miles west of Stornoway. Truly unforgettable.The amazingly preserved broch at Carloway,  miles from Stornoway, is more than  years old and offers a unique insight into Iron Age le.The stunning white sands at Uig, on the west coast of Lewis, seem to go on forever, rivalling even the best beaches on nearby Harris.

title: Iain Macwhirter  May   s done the impossible - brought Leave and Remainers together  but only against her
story: The Prime Minister made a dignied, resilient stand last week, before a House of Commons that loathes this proposal. But theres a time when resilience turns into defiance, and then defiance turns into delusion. Theresa Mayrsquos staying power is the nations curse, as she perseveres with a orce deal which has no hope. She has finally united Leavers and Remainers, but only to the extent that theyrsquore against her. Shes lost both her Brexit Secretaries, a host of ministers and both houses of parliament. But, like Monty Pythonrsquos limbless Black Knight, she battles on regardless.MPs on all sides say the European Court of Justice will continue to have effective jurisdiction over UK laws on things like state aid, labour conditions, environmental standards and tax. Theresa May insists it wonrsquot, and that by , a deep and meaningful future trading relationship will have been negotiated, which will make the backstop unnecessary. But that is a triumph of hope over experience. No one has yet come up with a way of ensuring frictionless trade that doesnt involve either membership of the Customs Union, or accepting many of the rules of the European Single Market. If you keep all or part of the single market you keep the ECJ.This doesnt mean that the ECJ is involved in every negotiation. There is to be an arbitration  to sort out everyday problems between the EU and UK. But when it comes to a dispute on EU law, the ECJ rulings are final. That is crystal clear in Article  of the Withdrawal Agreement which says that the ECJ ldquoshall have jurisdiction to make such a ruling, which will be binding on the arbitration .Theres nothing sinister in this ndash except in the eyes of paranoid europhobes. When you join a tennis club, no one complains that your rights and liberties are being removed just because you accept the rules. The real issue is whether you have any say in the making of them. Democracy demands that members of an international trading organisation should have have a share in the decision-making process. This is where the Withdrawal Agreement, indeed the whole Brexit project falls down, because as things stand, we dont. We will be rule takers.Theresa May realised very early on that the economic cost of leaving the EU completely was just too high. She gave assurances to all those big international companies like Nissan, Siemens and Rolls Royce, who have complex, just-in-time supply chains, that she would negotiate a deal that was at least as good as the single market. She effectively promised no tarfs, border checks or regulatory issues ndash ie no ldquofriction - between Britain and the EU. She had to, or theyd have upped and left . Components for Vauxhall cars are said to cross and recross EU borders at least  times before theyre finally assembled in Ellesmere Port.But removing tarf and non-tarf barriers is precisely what the Customs Union and the European Single Market were originally created to do. The EU is first of all a free trade area, the most comprehensive in the world. When Britain decided to leave, it meant that frictions would inevitably . Theresa May has been trying to square the circle ever since: getting the benefits of a single market without being in it.Shes achieved quite a lot, to give her credit. Under her orce deal, Britain gets broad access in to the single market in goods without having to accept free movement. But the cost was always going to be some continued observance of the EUrsquos regulations, plus ECJ oversight. Weve had to agree to ldquodynamic alignment with EU regulations, meaning that when they change in future Britain will have to go along with the new rules.The obvious solution might be to just join the single market, as Norway did after . It is not in the EU, the Common Fisheries Policy or the Common Agricultural Policy. This is Nicola Sturgeons preferred option, and she said last week thatScotland even got the same deal as Northern Ireland, which is to remain largely in the ESM, she would vote for the Withdrawal Agreement. But while this Norway option has worked after a fashion, it has powerful critics. It costs quite a lot, and there have long been complaints in Oslo about ldquofax democracy - that new laws are simply faxedfrom Brussels. But hey ndash thats just how these things work. You are either in the EU or you arent.So what happens now  Mays deal wont fly, yet she stands her ground. The deal will almost certainly be rejected in parliament, even though Labour dont really have a coherent alternative. Jeremy Corbyn was scathing about Mayrsquos ldquobotched deal, but he too wants to leave the EU. Nor do Labour wish Britain to be a formal member of the Customs Union or the European Single Market. John McDonnell, the Shadow Chancellor, says he would renegotiate the deal to achieve a ldquoclose and collaborative relationship with the single market. In other words, a better deal than Mayrsquos. But the German Chancellor, Angela Merkell, has made clear that negotiations are over. End of story.Faced with a disastrous no deal, and no prospect of renegotiating the Withdrawal Agreement, the opposition parties face a very hard parliamentary choice next month. Do they join with Jacob Rees Mogg and the DUP, and vote for an economic disaster which would damage the livelihoods of countless Labour voters  Or do they suck it up, back Theresa May and then blame the Tories in future for landing Britain with such a bad settlement  If they vote down Mayrsquos orce deal, they must know that renegotiation is not now an option. Nor is a general election, because the Tories wonrsquot vote, like turkeys, for an early Christmas. The only alternative is for the opposition parties to do what they should have done months ago: unite the Remain majority in the House of Commons to demand a delay on Article , and then force May to hold a repeat referendum.If parliament cant decide what to do, the only option is to hand it back to the people who got us into this mess in the first place: the voters.

title: the-cool-list-hotels
story: Built in  by Lord MacDonald of Sleat and once surrounded by orange trees ndash hence the hotelrsquos name ndash Marmalade is a -minute walk from Portree harbour and offers fine views over Portree Bay and to the Cuillins beyond. Butthe exterior is resolutely Georgian, the interior is st century to the max ndash the  rooms have a chic, pared-back Scandinavian feel and a colour palette of mustard and grey. As the name suggests, the hotelrsquos Chargrill Restaurant specialises in grilled steak and seafood and therersquos an emphasis on locally-grown and locally-sourced produce. That ethos extends beyond the dining room: many of the hotel textiles, such as the throws which cover the beds, are made by local company Skye Weavers on their bicycle-powered looms. How cool is that Fingal, EdinburghBuilt in  by the Scotstoun-based Blythswood yard, the Leith-registered MV Fingal spent most of its working le as a Northern Lighthouse Board ship working out of Oban and Stromness. And now that it has been ed to Leith and berthed near to the Royal Yacht Britanniaitrsquos seeing out its days as hellip a luxury hotel of course, what   Each cabin is named after a Stevenson lighthouse but therersquos more than a touch of old-style ocean liner luxury to the rooms. Asthat wasnrsquot the perfect excuse to unleash your inner Bing Crosby or Ginger Rogers therersquos also a magnicent ballroom with a sweeping staircase. Just one snag, though: after a delay in gaining the green light from the capitalrsquos planning panjandrums, the hotel wonrsquot now open until January.Isle of Eriska Hotel  Spa, ObanWho hasnrsquot wanted to live on their own private island  At the Isle of Eriska Hotel you can,only for a few nights ndash covering  acres itrsquos located at the mouth of Loch Creran,  miles north of Oban, and offers fine views over Loch Linnhe and the Morvern mountains beyond. There are  bedrooms in the main house, built by acclaimed Scottish architect Hippolyte Blanc in  for a branch of the Stewarts of Appin, as well as five spa suites in the garden, two cottages and six ldquohilltop reserves complete with hot tubs and balconies. The sumptuous dining room specialises in game and seafood and therersquos a cornucopia of spa treatments on offer as well as a -metre swimming pool, a sauna, a steam room, a jacuzzi and a gym. Andyoursquore the time-poor, cash-rich sort that takes leisure seriously and isnrsquot prepared to waste time travelling, the hotel can accommodate helicopters and sea planes. Tides permitting, of course.Bauhaus Hotel and Kitchen, AberdeenDesigned by the late Edinburgh-born architect Bob Fitzgerald, this chic city centre hotel was inspired by the simplicity and famously clean lines of Germanyrsquos Bauhaus art school. The homage even extends to the names of the rooms ndash here you can stay in suites named after Walter Gropiusand Wassily Kandinsky , as well as other early th century design luminaries such as husband-and-we team Charles and Ray Eames, of Eames chair fame. Art history lessons aside, therersquos a bar serving cocktails and afternoon tea, though the hotel kitchen serves only breakfast. For anything  yoursquoll have to hit the streets, though the hotelrsquos central location means yoursquore spoiled for choice.Blythswood Square Hotel, GlasgowIts not unusual for the stars to stay in Glasgows only five star hotel when in town, with Sir Tom Jones a recent guest. The seven storey hotel now boasts a luxury two bedroom penthouse apartment, complete with private lt, wet room, dining room and roof garden. For a real taste of how the other half le, you can even avail yourself of the services of a private chef and butler. If your budget doesnt quite stretch to the pound, tag, however, the hotel - once townhouses owned by the citys wealthy merchants - has more than  bedrooms . After sipping a cocktail or two in the elegant Salon, guests can treat themselves in the spa, or even get a haircut with a barber shop and beauty salon on site.Greywalls, East LothianBuilt in  in the Arts and Craft style by the celebrated Edwardian architect Sir Edwin Lutyens and used as a country house by several well-heeled owners, among them the Hon. Alfred Lyttelton and Scottish-American socialite Evelyn Forbes, Greywalls also served as a military hospital during the second world war. It wasnrsquot until  that it became a hotel by which point it had been added to by another famous architect, Sir Robert Lorimer, and had had a garden laid out by the inestimable Gertrude Jekyll. She also designed the amazing garden overlooking Lindisfarne Castle on Lindisfarne, another Lutyens project. Itrsquos no surprise, then, that today Greywalls is a Category A-listed building with prices to match. Handy for the adjacent Muirfield golf course and renowned for its restaurantitrsquos easily one of Scotlandrsquos coolest hotels. King Edward VII, Barbra Streisand and Brigitte Bardot certainly thought so: theyrsquore just a few of the celebrities who have stayed there.Monachyle Mhor, Lochearnhead, PerthshireFancy ditching the traditional hotel room and staying instead in a s Pilot Panther showmanrsquos wagon  Or how about the old waiting room from the Port Appin to Isle of Lismore ferry, renovated and repurposed and turned into a cosy double located next to a chic bothy with a wood-burning stove designed by two architecture students  Trip along to Monachyle Mhor and you can lay your head in these and other dwellings, each as cool and quirky as the rest. There are six ldquofeature rooms, six courtyard rooms, and four whitewashed and coolly spartan farmhouse rooms. The hip factor doesnrsquot stop there, either. The award-winning restaurant uses locally-sourcedproduce and the Lewis family who own Monachyle Mhor also have their own bakery turning out that artisan sourdough wersquore all so fond of these days.Z Glasgow, GlasgowLocated just off George Square in a converted print works and boasting  rooms, Z Glasgow is one of a group of similarly-named hotels with several branches in Londonas well as in Liverpool and Bath. Z Glasgowrsquos mission statement makes clear itrsquos aimed unashamedly at what it calls ldquourbanites rather than tourists, and truth to tell the rooms arenrsquot massive. Then again, urbanites donrsquot visit Glasgow to sit around watching Cash In The Attic ndash they go there to shop, visit top cultural destinations such as the nearby Gallery of Modern Art and to sample the legendary nightle. They tend to eat out as well, so Z Glasgow dispenses with room service and provides Z Cafeacute instead offering breakfasts, light lunches and pre-theatre drinks.Crossbasket Castle, BlantyreFormerly a Barnardorsquos home, an educational college, a centre for a Pentacostal ministry and at one time the residence of Charles Macintosh of raincoat fame, this grand old building was restored in  and now boasts a Roux Brothers restaurantand bills itself as one of Scotlandrsquos most luxurious hotels. Few who visit would argue. Prime among the palatial suites is one with its own tower, though you can also choose to stay in the less grandiose Gate Lodge. The grounds, meanwhile, contain river-side nature walks and therersquos even a waterfall thoughyou want to venture further afield, you can arrange to have a Range Rover delivered direct to the hotel. Theyrsquoll even lay on a helicopteryou need one.Corsewall Lighthouse Hotel, Dumfries and GallowayLocated in the northern Rhinns of Galloway and still a working lighthouse, Corsewall offers a ied selection of suites and rooms both in the main building itself and in adjacent buildings. Built in  and now A-listed it offers views of the Kintyre peninsula, Ailsa Craig and, on a clear day, the coast of Ireland. Itrsquos ideal for golfersas well as birdwatchers and walkers drawn by the rugged coastline. And, of course, it will appeal to lighthouse nerds: at night you can see the beams of several Scottish and Irish lighthouses and both Mull of Galloway and Killantringan light houses are a short drive away. The restaurant is small but comfortable and typical dishes include Galloway pork fillet, smoked chicken, Scotch beef and roast monkfish.Tigerlily, EdinburghSited in a grand Georgian building on George Street in Edinburghrsquos New Town, this boutique hotel is one of the capitalrsquos liveliest upmarket spots ndash expect to find footballers partying in the bar alongside the hip visitors and well-heeled locals. It has a -strong cocktail menu overseen by an award-winning ldquomixologist and next door in the restaurant you can take afternoon tea or sample a menu that runs from the comfortingto the indulgent . Upstairs the rooms are coolly elegant, thoughitrsquos character you want head for The Black Room. Located at the top of the building it has walls the colour of ebony and one of those iconic s-style wicker ldquoegg chairs suspended from the ceiling by a chain.

title: nicola-sturgeon-poised-for-downing-st-showdown-with-theresa-may-as-brexit-tensions-rise
story: In another critical week for her premiership, the Prime Minister continues to face the threat of a no-confidence vote by Tory rebels last night she held private talks with Brexiteers and former Cabinet ministers Iain Duncan Smith and Owen Paterson to quell the rebellion.However, by this morning, the  signatures needed to trigger the ballot were still not forthcoming only  Conservative MPs have publicly admitted to handing in letters calling for a vote.This morning, Mrs May chaired Cabinet,facingdown any calls from colleagues to tweak the withdrawal agreement. She will visit Brussels tomorrowto meet Jean-Claude Juncker, the Commission President, to try to sign off the future framework dealahead of Sundays special EU summit.The First Minister, beforeher scheduled meeting with Mrs May today, claimed the PMrsquos insistence that the choice before MPs between her draft withdrawal agreement and a no-deal was a  one.ldquoThis is a time for grown-up, responsible governance in the public interest, declared Ms Sturgeon, ldquosomething which has been sadly lacking to date as the Tory Party has continued to put its own interests ahead of the interests of jobs, communities and businesses.ldquoIt mustnrsquot be an option between frying pan or fire but it is now incumbent on all of us who oppose that  choice to propose a workable alternative.The FM is also due to have a private Commons meeting with Labour leader Jeremy Corbynthis lunch-time to push a united front for continued single market and customs union membership as an alternative to a no-deal scenario.To the same end, she is also due to hold talks with Sir Vince Cable, the Liberal Democrat leader, Liz Saville Roberts for Plaid Cymru and Caroline Lucas for the Greens. The issue of pushing for a Peoples Vote is also likely to come up.Last night, Labourrsquos Sir Keir Starmer said Labour could even try to bring down the Conservative Government to block a no-deal Brexit.The Shadow Brexit Secretary told the Parliamentary Labour Party he was prepared to ldquowork with all sides to prevent the UK crashing out of the EU without a deal."There will be opportunities to make the majority against no-deal heard. Motions will be tabled, amendments will be pressed and a no-confidence vote can be triggered.If a no-confidence motion passed, a new government would have to be formed within  days and win its own confidence voteit failed, there would be a general election.In Whitehall yesterday, the SNPrsquos Michael Russell, attending his th Joint Ministerial Committee, brushed aside questions about Ms Sturgeon calling for a second independence referendum, insisting the ldquofirst priority was to stop what he branded a disastrous withdrawal agreement.Claiming UK ministers had lost ldquoall sense of reason, the Scottish Governmentrsquos Constitutional Relations Secretary declared: ldquoIt is an emergency for all the nations in these islands to stop this deal.But, post the fiery JMC, Mr Mundell launched a withering attack on the motives of the SNP leadership.Claiming the worst possible outcome for Scotland and the UK would be a no-deal, he declared: ldquoWhat the SNP are looking to achieve is chaos...because they believe thatrsquos the best way to take forward their independence agenda.He added: ldquoIf there is a majority in the House of Commons against this deal, we risk a no-deal Brexit and a disastrous outcome for Scotland.Mr Mundell was also pressed on the issue of including UK fishing rights in any extension to the -month transition period.ldquoIm very clear we cant extend the period and include the Common Fisheries Policy within that extension and I could not support that, he insisted.Askedhe would therefore resignBritain remained bound by CFP rules beyond December , the Secretary of State replied: ldquoIm not playing into the resign soap opera. What Im focused on is outcomes and we want the best outcome for Scotland."Earlier on Monday, the PM, following a speech to the CBI, pointed to the possibility of extending the transition period but noting how this should not go beyond the General Election scheduled for June .While the draft withdrawal agreement simply points to both sides using their ldquobest endeavours to get a post-transition agreement on fishing by June , No  admitted the issue of UK fishing rights would be part of the negotiations.ldquoThese are all things that would have to be discussed, said a spokesman.

title: theresa-may-off-to-brussels-to-complete-brexit-deal-with-jean-claude-juncker
story: Downing Street said the meeting was part of the "ongoing negotiations over the future framework" agreement with the EU.It is understood the talks are set to focus on future long-term relations between the UK and EU, rather than on the withdrawal deal that the Prime Minister unveiled last week.The move follows a stormy few days for Mrs May, which have seen the DUP deliver a warning shot across Government bows after accusing her of breaking fundamental promises on Brexit.And a number of Tory MPs are still pushing for a vote of confidence in the PM, although their attempts to topple her appear, for the moment, to have stalled.David Gauke, the Justice Secretary, said a move to oust Mrs May would be "dangerous for the country".He told BBC Breakfast: "The idea that at this point, in the middle of a very delicate negotiation, that is hugely important to the future of this country, that we should remove the Prime Minister, essentially leave us leaderless, for certainly several weeks, possibly months, would be hugely irresponsible."I dont think people should be talking about removing her at this point. That would be self-indulgent and dangerous for the country."In another cause for concern for the PM, Mrs Mays Spanish counterpart Pedro Sanchez said Madrid would vote against the withdrawal deal at a special EU summit on SundayGibraltars future was not considered a bilateral issue between the UK and Spain.ldquoIn the past  hours, none of the documents has claried something which is fundamental for us: Gibraltar is not part of the UK, declared Mr Sanchez.ldquoAs a country, we cannot assume what is going to happen in the future with regard to GibraltarhellipIt should be negotiated between Spain and the UK. As it stands, the [Spanish] government will vote against the Brexit agreement," insisted the socialist leader in Madrid.Meanwhile, the DUP showed its anger with Mrs Mays Brexit deal by joining with Labour to cut the Governments majority to just five in a Commons vote on the Budget.It also abstained on a series of other amendments to the Finance Bill on Monday night, in a move intended to send a "political message" to the PM.Their actions appeared to call into question the future of the "confidence and supply" arrangement by which the DUP props up Mrs Mays minority Conservative Government.Under the terms of the deal, agreed after the Tory leader lost her Commons majority in last years General Election, the Northern Ireland party is supposed to back the Government on Budget matters and on confidence votes.But Sammy Wilson, the partyrsquos Brexit spokesman, said Mrs Mays deal with Brussels breached a "fundamental" assurance that Northern Ireland would not be separated constitutionally or economically from the rest of the UK."We had to do something to show our displeasure," he declared.In a bid to sway opinion, Mrs May has insisted that her draft Brexit deal puts Northern Ireland in a "fantastic position" for the future.In an opinion piece published in the Belfast , the PM claimed the regions constitutional status within the UK had been guaranteed in the agreement.Mrs May acknowledged that there had been a lot of focus on the Irish border "backstop" and said she "understood and share some of the concerns that have been expressed".But she argued the backstop was an "acceptable insurance policy" due to provisions in the deal.The DUP warning adds to the pressure on the PM just as the Tory bid to unseat her by Brexiteers appeared to have stuttered.Members of the Conservative European Research Group were last week confidently predicting they would get the  letters of no confidence needed to trigger a vote in her leadership.However, there has been no announcement from Sir Graham Brady, the Chairman of the backbench  Committee, saying that they have reached that tally, while the number of MPs who have publicly declared they submitted letters remains in the twenties.There were also reports that the so-called "pizza club" group of Cabinet Brexiteers was backing away from a plan to go to Mrs May to demand she re-opens negotiations with Brussels on a key element of the agreement.Michael Gove - who last week turned down the job of Brexit Secretary following the resignation of Dominic Raab - Andrea Leadsom, Penny Mordaunt, Liam Fox and Chris Grayling were all reported to be unhappy with the terms over the Northern Irish border.However, there was little sign that they were preparing to force a fresh showdown at the weekly meeting of the Cabinet in Downing Street on Tuesday, which was expected to last longer than the usual hour due to the circumstances.Elsewhere, in a further sign of the Governments weakness, ministers were forced to offer fresh concessions to stave off a damaging defeat over the publication of the Governments assessment of the economic impact of Brexit.Robert Jenrick, the Treasury Minister, told MPs they would now release a comparative analysis of the economic impactBritain was to remain in the EU rather than leave in March .Previously, the Government had only undertaken to publish its assessment of the impact of leaving with a deal, compared with a no-deal Brexit.

title: nicola-sturgeon-admits-indyref2-may-be-after-2021

same terminology as the EU referendum was applied to independence.However this feel to - for Remainthere was a No Deal Brexit.The SNP were at % on Westminster voting intention, compared to % for the continue to be sidelined by Westminster.ldquoIt seems this poll was commissioned by our opponents to land a political blow on the SNP, whereas itrsquos had the exact opposite effect. These figures make extremely encouraging reading for the independence movement while leaving the Tory and Labour parties extremely downhearted. title: now-or-never-jacob-rees-mogg-pressures-colleagues-to-topple-theresa-may-quickly
story: Amid signs the attempt by Tory rebels to force a vote of confidence in the Prime Minister has stalled, the Somerset MP acknowledged they were struggling to get the support they needed.:Mundell says catastrophic No Deal Brexit would threaten UnionHowever, Mr Rees-Mogg, who leads the pro-Brexit European Research Group [ERG] insisted there was little enthusiasm among Tory MPs for Mrs May to take them into the next election, due in ."It is now or the Prime Minister will lead the Conservatives into the next election," he told reporters at a Westminster news conference.Last week, senior ERG figures were confidently predicting they would get the  letters of no-confidence from MPs needed to trigger a vote in Mrs Mays leadership.But with Brexiteers apparently ided over whether it was the right time to mount a challenge, the prospect of them achieving their target appeared to be dwindling.Yet Mr Rees-Mogg warned that they needed to consider whether they really wanted to carry on with her at the helm.While party rules would permit a fresh challenge in a years timethere were a failed attempt now, he said that in practice it was doubtful that would happen."Basically,there is a vote of confidence it is not just for a year. Getting the  letters has shown to be quite dficult, so the idea that in a year you just repeat the process and then she would go at that point, I dont think that is realistic," explained the Tory backbencher.Askedhis attempt to unseat the Prime Minister had been exposed as a "Dads Army" operation, Mr Rees-Mogg replied: "Ive always admired Captain Mainwaring."Senior ministers sought to rally round Mrs May, with David Gauke, the Justice Secretary, warning that any move to oust her would be "dangerous for the country".He told BBC Breakfast: "The idea that at this point, in the middle of a very delicate negotiation, that is hugely important to the future of this country, that we should remove the Prime Minister, essentially leave us leaderless, for certainly several weeks, possibly months, would be hugely irresponsible."I dont think people should be talking about removing her at this point. But she added the backstop was an "acceptable insurance policy" due to provisions in the deal.

title: celtic-contributes-165m-to-scottish-economy-finds-new-study
story: Analysis of the clubs activities and spending by spectators at home and away matches over the - season also found the club helps to support , jobs.:Scotland are benefitting from having a strong core of Celtic playersThe Fraser of Allander Institute said the club recorded turnover of over pound million in -, hosted around . million attendances at matches in Glasgow and competed in matches where almost two million people attended.Economists said despite the focus on figures for the - season, similar levels of economic activity will be supported each and every year.On a net basis - adjusting for the impact of spending which is not additional to the Scottish economy - Celtic were found to make an economic contribution of pound million, helping to support around , jobs.Celtic commissioned the report by the institute at the University of Strathclyde "because of a feeling that the economic contribution from football in general and Celtic in particular is consistently undervalued".Professor Graeme Roy, director at the Fraser of Allander Institute, said: "What is particularly interesting from our findings is the value of international spending that is attracted to Glasgow via Celtic."This acts as an export for Scotland boosting jobs and supporting growth."This suggests that there is an opportunity to use regular major events - such as Scottish football - as a lever to help support economic development.":Re-emergence of Jonny Hayes and Lewis Morgan debut gives Celtic reasons for cheerCeltic chief executive Peter Lawwell said: "While a huge amount of attention is rightly paid to one-off events like the Commonwealth Games and other activities which attract interest to Scotland and Glasgow, footballs economic contribution tends to be overlooked - yet it brings people here from around the world."He added: "There is a great deal in this report for the club and its supporters to take pride in."We also hope that the Scottish Government and Glasgow City Council will recognise that Celtic and football more generally are signicant economic players when it comes to issues like transportation links and tourism promotion."

title: the-herald-diary-im-a-celebrityget-me-out-of-brexit
story: THE news story about the statue being unveiled to Lisbon Lion Bobby Lennox reminds entertainer Andy Cameron: "The charity side Dukla Pumpherston were playing down south, and on the bus somebody suggested that Bobby entertain the company. A Rangers player bet Bobby that he couldnt sing The Sash. Of course, ah can, says Bobby and started, Sure itrsquos old and it is beautulrsquo then stopped. He then explained, Thats all ah know because at that point we always scored, and the Rangers supporters shut up."Key to finding itTHE things children say.
